item.title: Developing on Amazon Linux 2 using Windows | Amazon Web Services
item.description: See how to get the best of both Windows and Linux as your development environment all on the same machine. Run the Amazon Linux 2 distribution via the Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 and leverage the Visual Studio Code Remote – WSL extension, AWS Toolkit for Visual Studio Code, and the AWS SAM CLI to provide a frictionless development experience.

item.title: Microsoft brings Azure supercomputing to UK Met Office

item.title: Dive into the AWS SDK for .NET’s Runtime Pipeline and Client Configuration | Amazon Web Services
item.description: Improve your application’s performance and make your application more resilient to transient errors by seeing how to configure settings such as maximum length to wait for a request to complete, or specify API request retry behavior. Learn what the AWS SDK for .NET's runtime pipeline is and how to customize it and even how to add your own behaviors to each API request.

item.title: Argentine version of Google falls into “wrong” hands leading to search engine's temporary collapse
item.description: An Argentine internet user claimed realized ownership of the google.com.ar domain had expired Wednesday, April 21 and since it was available, he decided to purchase it for reportedly AR $ 540 (around the US $ 3.85 at the unofficial exchange rate) leading to a temporary shutdown of the search engine ending in “.ar”.

item.title: My New Setup - Road to the Valhalla
item.description: It’s been a long time since I wrote something in the blog. A lot of things happened since my last blogpost. One of the interesting things that I’ve been into is working on my new setup. This post is the first of a series of articles about my new setup. I’ll share with you the things I added to (and removed from) my workflow, and how they benefited me. The big problem: Hardware My job and my research as a systems' engineer requires from me to create clusters of VMs (and containers) in order to simulate various environnements and architecures.
item.author: (Iduoad)

item.title: We need to talk about your Q3 roadmap
item.description: As people complete their vaccination schedule, as the world around us continues to burn, and as the product roadmap chugs along, something’s gotta give. And I think it’s going to be your feature plans—because the humans behind them need time to recuperate.

item.title: C++ coroutines: Improving cold-start coroutines which complete synchronously | The Old New Thing
item.description: Last time, we learned that the naïve implementation of cold-start coroutines is susceptible to stack build-up. What we want is for await_suspend to return false if the coroutine completed synchronously. This is tricky because that reintroduces a race condition where the coroutine runs asynchronously and completes at the same time we try to transition from synchronous to asynchronous behavior in the awaiter.
item.author: (Raymond Chen)

item.title: Tiny Container Challenge: Building a 6kB Containerized HTTP Server!
item.description: TL;DR I set out to build the smallest container image that I could that was still able to do something useful. By taking advantage of multistage builds, the scratch base image, and a tiny assembly based http server, I was able to get it down to 6.32kB!

item.title: Welcome! You are invited to join a meeting: Building real-time web apps with SignalR (presented by David Fowler from Microsoft). After registering, you will receive a confirmation email about joining the meeting.
item.description: SignalR is a free and open-source software library for Microsoft ASP.NET that allows server code to send asynchronous notifications to client-side web applications. The library includes server-side and client-side JavaScript components
